In this study, density functional theory was used to investigate the differences of oxygen reduction reaction catalytic activities between pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N doped graphene quantum dots (GQDs) and the influence of four ions/groups: OH–, H3O+, OH and H3O on their electronic properties. Free energy change calculations show that pyridinic-N doped GQDs (pN-GQDs) have better catalytic activities than pyrrolic-N doped GQDs (prN-GQDs). Moreover, the catalytic activity of both pN-GQDs and prN-GQDs can be enhanced via the functionalization of OH and H3O groups, which greatly alters electronic structures of the GQDs and thereby the adsorption strength of reactants can be effectively controlled. The findings can shed light on the effects of different N doping configurations and adsorbed species on electrocatalytic activities and provide theoretical guidelines for design and development of carbon-based oxygen reduction reaction electrocatalysts for fuel cells and metal-air batteries. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Graphene quantum dots Pyridinic-N doping Pyrrolic-N doping Oxygen reduction reaction Density functional theory Data availability All data used to generate the results in this paper can be obtained from the corresponding authors upon reasonable request. 1 Introduction Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) plays a vital role in renewable energy conversion and storage devices, such as fuel cells and metal-air batteries. Despite their promising and tremendous potentials, fuel cells demand more efficient catalysts due to the fact that the cathode suffers from sluggish kinetics of ORR compared with anode [1]. Although Pt and its alloys are efficient catalysts, especially in acidic environment, high cost and low tolerance to methanol and CO restrict their overall performances [2–4]. It is estimated that Pt catalysts count more than half of the cost of fuel cells [5,6]. Consequently, comprehensive investigations have been devoted to find low-cost and efficient alternatives in past few decades. For example, metal-containing materials including single-atom catalysts and metal-organic frameworks have become electrocatalytic reaction alternative catalysts due to their tunable structures, large surface area and high porosity [7–9,10]. Single-atom catalysts can fully utilize metal atoms to achieve high activity and selectivity in heterogeneous catalysis [7,8], and dual-metal-organic frameworks not only possess high thermodynamical stability, but also exhibit excellent bifunctional electrocatalytic activities for ORR and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [9]. In addition, metal-containing electrocatalysts can have multifunctional electrocatalytic activities and high stability through anchoring single-atoms on two-dimensional materials. For instance, the ORR/OER catalytic activities of Ni atoms with vanadium disulfide monolayers were comparable to Pt- and Ru-based catalysts or even higher [11]. Pd catalysts on MoSe2 monolayer exhibited bifunctional electrocatalytic activities with high efficiency for ORR/OER, and Ni atoms on MoSe2 also displayed excellent OER performances with a low overpotential of 0.47 V [12]. Meanwhile, Si-doped graphene with indium-based bimetallic clusters could catalyze ORR, OER and hydrogen evolution reaction with relatively low overpotentials as trifunctional electrocatalyst, which resulted from electronic structures regulated by synergistic effects between bimetallic clusters and Si-doped graphene [10]. The iron-nitrogen-carbon catalysts via the incorporation of B atoms based on graphene also improved oxygen electrocatalytic activities. It was found that the environment of coordinating active sites could play an important role in enhancing catalytic properties of single-atom catalysts for ORR/OER [13]. Among numerous candidates, metal-free based carbon materials have also become desirable catalysts for ORR, such as fullerenes, carbon nanotubes, and graphene [14–16]. Graphene has many properties similar to metal-containing electrocatalysts which are conducive to electrocatalysis, such as high electrical conductivity. Besides, dimensional controllability and versatility of C–C bonds of graphene can also contribute to ORR catalytic activity [17]. Notably, when the lateral size of graphene is reduced to 10 nm, the new material is generally called graphene quantum dot (GQD), which shows tremendous potential in the fields of energy storage and conversion [18,19]. Due to quantum-confinement and edge effects of zero-dimensional GQDs, doping GQDs with heteroatoms could alter their electronic characteristics largely and introduce new properties [20]. For example, GQDs doping with heteroatoms (i.e., N, S, P, B, F) exhibit high ORR and/or OER catalytic activities [5,21,22]. Especially, N heteroatoms in graphene can have different N-doped configurations, such as graphitic-N, pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N [1,21]. However, it is still under debate which N-doped configuration possesses higher catalytic activity. Some suggested that graphitic-N is responsible for the ORR activity of N-doped carbon. The Gibbs free-energy change in the first-electron step of graphitic-N bonding configurations was lower than those of pyridinic-and pyrrolic-N bonding configurations through theoretical calculations [23]. However, other researchers reported that pyridinic-N or pyrrolic-N exhibited high ORR catalytic activity [14,24,25]. N-doped holey graphene with high edge pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N demonstrated outstanding ORR performances and better stability than Pt/C [26]. Similarly, N-doped graphene with pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N showed better catalytic activities toward ORR, and carbon atoms adjacent to pyridinic- and pyrrolic-N were claimed as catalytic active sites [14,27]. In addition, some reported that the promotion of catalytic activity is determined by pyrrolic-N since increased proportion of pyrrolic-N in graphene was the main reason for enhanced catalytic activity [27,28]. Thus, in this study, we will explore the catalytic performance of pyridinic-N doped GQDs (pN-GQDs) and pyrrolic-N doped GQDs (prN-GQDs) to better understand catalyst mechanisms of ORR underlying difference N-doped bonding configurations. On the other hand, functionalization also plays an important role in tailoring catalytic properties [29]. In electrochemistry, the ORR catalytic performance of carbon nanotubes, graphene and other carbon materials can be enhanced by some functionalization of ions or groups. For instance, hydroxyl ion (OH−) as an electron donor can increase electron donating ability to promote reaction process [30]. As for ORR, OH– can promote the O2 dissociative pathway. It has been stated that the adsorbed OH– ions on the surface are correlated with the associative 4e– reduction region, while the absence of OH– lead to the dissociative 2e– pathway [31]. The aqueous hydronium ion (H3O+) is also a kind of ions which play an important role in many chemical reactions [32]. What's more, aqueous solution is found to have certain effects on catalytic performances of GQDs [33]. However, what remains unclear is how OH− and H3O+ affect intrinsic properties of GQDs and their ORR catalytic activity in aqueous solution. In our previous studies, we investigated graphitic-N doped GQDs (gN-GQDs) with four ions and groups (OH−, H3O+, OH and H3O) [34]. Hence, in this study, we analyze influences of four different ions and groups on ORR catalytic activities of pN-GQDs and prN-GQDs using density functional theory (DFT) and compare them with gN-GQDs. It is anticipated that these findings can help to understand the roles of functionalization ions and groups on GQDs and provide insights for designing and synthesizing heteroatoms doped GQDs for metal-air batteries and fuel cells. 2 Calculation method All DFT calculations were performed using the B3LYP hybrid method with basis set of 6-311G (d, p) [35,36] in Gaussian 09 packages [37]. Visualizations of molecular structures and electronic analysis were rendered with GaussView [38] and Multiwfn [39]. As one of the most popular methods to calculate the solvation Gibbs free energies of finite solutes in any solvent, the implicit solvation model density (SMD) was employed to investigate the solvation effect in water based on a continuum model of the solvent [40–42]. In this study, based on the implicit solvation model, the limited explicit solvation approach was explored by adding one ion or group. This means, explicit and implicit solvation models were combined to evaluate the interaction between ions/groups and GQDs in bulk solvent (water). Considering spin polarization effects, spin-unrestricted calculation was also used [43]. For the molecular finite model, the C47 (C47H17) was selected as initial GQD. The models of pyridinic- and pyrrolic-N doped GQDs were constructed according to different N bonding configurations experimentally observed in carbon-based materials [44,45]. Based on X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis, pN-GQD (C45H17N) was constructed with a hexagonal ring at the center of graphene and prN-GQD (C45H18N) with a pentagonal ring at the center. The schematic representations of N-doped GQDs are shown in Fig. 1 . Adsorption structures consist of four different ions and groups adsorbed on the surface of pN-GQD or prN-GQD: OH–, H3O+, OH and H3O, denoted as pN-X-GQD or prN-X-GQD (X= OH−, H3O+, OH and H3O). The thermochemistry of electrochemical reactions was studied using the computational hydrogen electrode method developed by Nørskov et al [46]. Previous theoretical calculations on GQDs were consistent with experimental results and gave reasonable insights to electrocatalytic ORR mechanisms [22,47–49]. For example, the calculations of ORR using N-doped GQDs revealed that pyridinic- and graphitic-N are most active sites with respective overpotentials of 0.55 V and 0.79−0.90 V, which agreed with experimental findings [48]. The introduction of S in N,S-doped GQDs could enhance the ORR electrocatalytic activity due to asymmetric spin and charge densities caused by synergetic effects of N and S [49]. Moreover, the finite model revealed the correlations between intrinsic properties of dopants and the performances of GQDs as bi-functional catalyst for ORR/OER [22]. The finite model is a method with less computationally cost to replace periodic method for calculating the properties of graphene. The finite model can describe localized properties and catalytic reactions at specific sites of graphene accurately as well as are consistent with the results of periodic models [50–52]. For instance, the spin density of B-doped circumcoronene molecular model (C54H18) with the doublet spin multiplicity was quite similar to the projected density of the highest half-filled band in the nonmagnetic ground state of periodic B-doped graphene and resulted in similar ORR reactivities [50]. Nevertheless, owing to energy minimization during structure optimization, the finite model has finite size effects and geometric distortion, which may differ from the results of periodic models [53]. Despite this, the hybrid functions can still give more accurate estimates to thermochemical overpotentials for graphene-based materials [53]. Therefore, the finite model C47 can be used to investigate ORR that occurs in surrounding region of N-doping and functional group sites. The formation energy (Ef ) was investigated to evaluate the stability of GQDs adsorbed with ions or groups: (1) E f = E pN / prN − X − GQD − E pN / prN − GQD − E X where EpN/prN-X-GQD, EpN/prN-GQD and EX are the total energy of pN-GQD or prN-GQD with adsorbed ion/group X, the energy of sole pN-GQD or prN-GQD and the energy of sole ion/group X, respectively. The negative value of Ef corresponds to a thermodynamic stable formation. In order to explore the stability of the molecular structures for the adsorption structures based on GQDs, Ab initio molecular dynamic simulations were performed using the atom centered density matrix propagation (ADMP) as implemented in Gaussian 09 software at B3LYP/6-311G (d,p) level of theory [54–56]. The optimized geometries of minimum energy of all structures were employed as the initial input for molecular dynamic simulations. The ADMP simulations were carried out for 25 femtoseconds (fs) for each structure with a time interval of 0.05 fs at 298 K. The solvent model SMD with water was also used for ADMP simulations. In electrochemistry, the ORR can proceed by a four electron-proton transfer pathway in acid solution. The reaction pathway was assumed to occur through associative mechanism with four intermediates (*OO, *OOH, *O and *OH) [46]. The elementary reaction steps can be expressed by the following equations: (2) * + O2 + H+ + e– → *OOH (3) *OOH + H+ + e– → *O + H2O (4) *O + H+ + e– → *OH (5) *OH + H+ + e– → * + H2O where * represents an active site on the surface of GQDs, and *OOH, *O and *OH are the adsorbed intermediates. The stability of different intermediates with GQDs was evaluated according to the adsorption energy (Eads ), which can be obtained using the following expressions: (6-1) E ads = E pN / prN − GQD − adso rbate − E pN / prN − GQD − E adso rbate (6-2) E ads = E pN / prN − X − GQD − adso rbate − E pN / prN − X − GQD − E adso rbate where EpN/prN-GQD-adsorbate, EpN/prN-X-GQD-adsorbate, EpN/prN-GQD, EpN/prN-X-GQD , and Eadsorbate represent the total energy of the pN-GQD or prN-GQD with adsorbed intermediates, pN-X-GQD or prN-X-GQD with adsorbed intermediates, the isolated pN-GQD or prN-GQD, the isolated pN-X-GQD or prN-X-GQD, and the sole intermediates, respectively. The negative value implies a favorable exothermic adsorption. Using the method proposed by Nørskov et al [46], the free energy changes of each elementary step can be calculated through this expression: (7) Δ G = Δ E + Δ ZPE − T Δ S + Δ G U + Δ G pH where ΔE, ΔZPE and ΔS are the energy change of each reaction step, change of zero-point energy and change of entropy, respectively, T is the temperature of 298 K. ΔGU = –neU, where n, e and U are the number of transferred proton-electron pairs, transferred charge and the electrode potential, respectively. ΔGpH = pH × kBTln10, and pH = 0 is employed in this work due to the reaction in acid solution. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Structures and electrostatic potential In order to compare and better explain the effects of functionalization on oxygen reduction reaction mechanisms, adsorption structures, including pN-GQDs and prN-GQDs with OH–, H3O+, OH, and H3O, were optimized based on energy minimization as shown in Figs. 2 and S1 in the Supporting Information (SI). Isolated pN-GQD retains the planar structure of graphene plane (Fig. 2a), while the plane of prN-GQD becomes uneven due to the pentagonal ring. Through the geometry optimization, it can be found that the positions of adsorbed ions and groups at the bottom right of graphene plane tend to have a more stable structure of adsorbed GQDs with a lower formation energy. The graphene plane has a certain distance from OH– and H3O+ ions, so the change of the graphene structure is slightly (Fig. 2b–c). In contrast, the H3O and OH groups form bonds with C atoms, inducing the C atom to move out of the plane of GQDs and form a tetrahedral structure with other three sp2 hybridization C atoms in graphene plane (Fig. 2d–e). For pN-H3O-GQD, the H3O structure consists of a separated H2O molecule and an H atom, the H atom forms a covalent bond with the C atom in GQDs and a hydrogen bond (around 2.45 Å) with O atom in H2O. As we know, the stability is critical for the success in the development of electrocatalysts. Hence, the comparisons of the formation energies Ef of the adsorption structures pN-GQDs and prN-GQDs with OH–, H3O+, OH, and H3O are listed in Table 1 to evaluate their stability. For example, the pN-OH–-GQD and prN-OH–-GQD are negative, which implies that these structures are easy to form. It indicates that the most stable and energetically favorable structures are pN-OH–-GQD and prN-OH–-GQD. The stability order of pN-GQDs adsorption structures is pN-OH–-GQD > pN-H3O-GQD > pN-OH-GQD > pN-H3O+-GQD, which is the same as that of prN-GQDs adsorption structures. The Ef values of pN-GQDs and prN-GQDs adsorption structures with the same species are close, which demonstrates that the type of species plays an important role in the stability of adsorption structures. Additionally, the dynamic evolution and the stability of all adsorption structures are further evaluated by using ADMP molecular dynamics method. Fig. S2 in SI exhibits the simulated trajectories of all structures by the variation of total energy change with time evolution. As shown in Fig. S2, the energy fluctuations of all structures are within 0.002 eV, indicating that the adsorption of ions and groups on GQDs are remarkable stable in molecular dynamics. Thus, it can be concluded that all adsorption structures exhibit considerable stability from both thermodynamics and dynamics perspectives, which may allow for potential applications as catalysts. Figs. 2 and S1 also show electrostatic potential (ESP) diagram of each adsorption structure in comparison with pN-GQD and prN-GQD. ESP is a description for the analysis of electrical properties and mechanisms, which can contribute to understand the influence of pyridinic-N dopant, pyrrolic-N dopant and adsorbed species on the stability of adsorbed states qualitatively. The area of negative ESP value corresponds to high electron density and the ability of attracting protons. Similarly, the area of positive ESP value corresponds to low electron density and the ability of repelling protons. As can be seen in Figs. 2(a) and S1(a), the area of negative charge are mainly distributed around the N atom, indicating that N-doping exerts a noteworthy influence on the charge arrangement of GQDs to produce more active sites. Due to the non-neutral state of pN-OH–-GQD, prN-OH–-GQD, pN-H3O+-GQD and prN-H3O+-GQD, the overall ESP distributions are changed greatly and become roughly negative and positive, respectively. So the electron density isosurface scales are adjusted and shown in Fig. S3 (from –0.1 to 0.01) and Fig. S4 (from –0.01 to 0.1). The negative and positive regions are surround OH– and H3O+, respectively. Comparing to OH– and H3O+ ions, the OH and H3O groups have a slight effect on altering the ESP distribution. Therefore, the OH– and H3O+ ions change the ESP distribution of local areas around them, while OH and H3O groups have an impact on the overall ESP distribution of pN-GQD and prN-GQD. 3.2 Electronic properties and active sites For the adsorption of ions and groups, the charge and spin density of GQDs are rearranged, which can introduce unanticipated active sites for ORR. So it is necessary to investigate the impacts of different ions and groups on GQDs electronic structures and properties. The catalytic active sites in carbon nanomaterials are substantially influenced by high spin density or high charge density of carbon atoms [34,57]. Furthermore, spin density of carbon atoms is the decisive factor of determining the position of O2 bonding [58]. Compounds have a spin multiplicity due to unpaired electrons, the pN-OH-GQD, pN-H3O-GQD, prN-GQD, prN-OH–-GQD, and prN-H3O+-GQD have doublet spin state. Hence, ORR active sites are chosen from the five highest charge density atoms of pN-GQD, pN-OH–-GQD, pN-H3O+-GQD, prN-OH-GQD and prN-H3O-GQD as well as the five highest spin density atoms of pN-OH-GQD, pN-H3O-GQD, prN-GQD, prN-OH–-GQD, and prN-H3O+-GQD. Due to the influence of non-neutral or singlet spin state, the O2 adsorption is not stable (e.g., C–O bond length > 2 Å in the adsorption configurations of O2 adsorbed on GQDs) at some highest charge density active sites of pN-GQD, pN-OH–-GQD, pN-H3O+-GQD and spin density active sites of prN-OH–-GQD. Consequently, the fifth, second, third highest charge density atom of pN-GQD, pN-OH–-GQD, pN-H3O+-GQD as well as the second highest spin density atom of prN-OH–-GQD with stable configuration of O2 adsorption are finally selected as active sites to study the ORR. The five highest charge density and spin density atoms are respectively marked by red circles and blue circles in Figs. S5 and S6, and the charge and spin density distribution of the GQDs with different ions and groups were calculated and listed in Table S1. For all GQDs structures (Figs. S5 and S6), the high charge density atoms are located around the N atom. In addition, the high spin density atoms are located around the adsorbed OH– and H3O+ ions in prN-GQDs, OH and H3O groups in pN-GQDs. From the specific charge density values of each atom in Table S1, it can be seen that OH– and H3O+ ions do not alter the charge density distribution of pN-GQD. For spin density values in Table S1, the OH– and H3O+ ions also do not change the spin density distribution of prN-GQD basically. Therefore, the influence of OH– and H3O+ ions on GQDs structure is weak due to the certain distance between them. It can be speculated that the OH– and H3O+ ions would have no remarkable change on the catalytic performance of pN-GQD and prN-GQD. However, the neutral OH and H3O groups which are bonded with GQDs can cause asymmetric distribution of atomic charge density and spin density. It infers that ORR catalytic activities are possibly affected by OH and H3O groups. 3.3 ORR intermediates adsorption configurations and stabilities The most energetically favorable configurations of O2 adsorption and the corresponding adsorption energies are displayed in Fig. 3 . After configuration optimization, there are two distinct adsorption configurations, which are Pauling mode and Bridge mode [59,60]. In Pauling mode one O atom bonds with single C atom and another O atom, while in Bridge mode two O atoms are bonded with two different C atoms separately. The C–O bond length is an average value of 1.48 Å in pN-GQDs (Fig. 3a) and 1.33 Å in prN-GQDs (Fig. 3b). In detail, the C–O bond lengths of pN-GQD, pN-OH–-GQD, pN-H3O+-GQD, pN-OH-GQD, and pN-H3O-GQD are 1.23 Å, 1.49 Å, 1.47 Å, 1.60 Å, and 1.62 Å; and those of prN-GQD, prN-OH–-GQD, prN-H3O+-GQD, prN-OH-GQD, and prN-H3O-GQD are 1.23 Å, 1.30 Å, 1.37 Å, 1.30 Å, and 1.46 Å, respectively. The relative stability can be compared from the adsorption energies in Fig. 3. The stability of O2 on pN-GQDs generally requires higher energy than prN-GQDs, which shows the configurations of O2 adsorbed on prN-GQDs are more thermodynamically favorable. Additionally, considering the relationship between C–O bond length and adsorption energy, lower adsorption energy often corresponds to shorter bond length. However, some studies suggest that too strong adsorption strength of reaction intermediates can hinder subsequent reaction steps of ORR on active sites [61]. The oxygen adsorption energies of some prN-GQDs structures are lower than –2 eV which suggest a strong bond strength and, as a result, prN-GQDs catalytic performance may be worse than pN-GQDs. The four electron-proton transfer pathway occurs through associative mechanism: different intermediates *OOH, *O and *OH are produced via hydrogenation and desorption steps. The adsorption energies and configurations of intermediates are displayed in Figs. 4 and S7, the negative adsorption energy implies that the adsorption process is exothermic and the intermediates can be easily adsorbed on the surface, so the adsorption structures are more thermodynamically stable. After the adsorption of oxygen is completed, the proton bonds with the top oxygen atom of *OO to form *OOH. In the second step, the proton continues to bond with the oxygen atom which has adsorbed a proton, the O–O bond breaks to generate the first water molecule, and the remaining oxygen atom still bonds with GQDs to form *O. Then it proceeds to bond with the third proton to form *OH, and in the last step, the *OH bonds with the last proton and desorbs to generate the second water molecule. The relative adsorption energies of these intermediates are similar to that of oxygen. As shown in Figs. 4 and S7, the adsorption energies of prN-GQDs are generally lower than those of pN-GQDs, which can attribute to stronger adsorption strength of oxygen. Moreover, the adsorption of some intermediates leads to the internal transfer of proton, the proton bonded with pyrrolic-N are captured by unsaturated carbon atoms on the defect ring. 3.4 Free energy changes for ORR To compare the catalytic activity of different pN-GQDs and prN-GQDs adsorption structures, the Gibbs free energy changes of each elementary step, as shown in Eqs. (2)–(5), were calculated by Eq. (7) and listed in Table 1. The free energy diagrams are presented in Fig. 5 . The ORRs in Fig. 5 proceed under equilibrium potential (Ueq = 1.23 V), and the free energy changes under zero potential are shown in Fig. S8. The overpotential can be obtained by Eq. (8) based on Norskov et al [62] and given in Table 1: (8) η O R R = 1.23 V + m a x { Δ G i } / e where ΔGi = ΔG1, ΔG2, ΔG3, ΔG4 , which are the Gibbs free energy changes of four reaction steps in Eqs. (2-5) respectively. As shown in Fig. S8(a), the first reaction step of pN-GQD, pN-OH–-GQD, pN-H3O+-GQD and pN-OH-GQD are endothermic, so these structures only have to overcome the barrier of first step, while pN-H3O+-GQD needs to overcome another barrier at the third step. It is reflected from the rate determination step (RDS, Table 1) that the first step is RDS for these four structures, which indicates these structures are harder to form *OOH. This reaction characteristic can illustrate they have similar catalytic abilities. Furthermore, all structures in the second reaction step are downhill in Fig. 5(a), which implies the forming of *O in all pN-GQDs structures is the step that promotes the reaction process. In particular, only pN-H3O-GQD has all downhill reaction steps, which are exothermic reactions under zero potential. And from the overpotentials listed in Table 1, the pN-H3O-GQD has the lowest value of 0.98 V. Based on the above discussions, the activity decreases in the order of: pN-H3O-GQD > pN-OH-GQD > pN-GQD > pN-H3O+-GQD > pN-OH–-GQD according to the value of overpotential, the pN-H3O-GQD has the highest catalytic activity among pN-GQDs. With regard to prN-GQDs (Table 1, Figs. 5b and S8b), the overpotentials of prN-GQD, prN-OH–-GQD and prN-H3O+-GQD under equilibrium potential are generally much higher than those of pN-GQDs, and the barriers to be overcome under zero potential are also much higher than those of pN-GQDs. So it can be concluded that the ORR catalytic activity of prN-GQDs is worse than pN-GQDs. In addition, the overpotentials of prN-GQD and prN-H3O+-GQD are very close, similar for pN-GQD and pN-H3O+-GQD, which indicates that H3O+ has small change in ORR catalytic activity of N-doped GQDs [34]. However, it is worth noting that prN-OH-GQD and prN-H3O-GQD still have lower overpotentials of 0.86 V and 1.03 V, respectively, with comparison to other prN-GQDs structures, and all reaction steps are exothermic. In connection with the above results of pN-GQDs, it can be concluded that OH and H3O groups can effectively enhance the ORR catalytic activity, which is consistent with our previous research [34]. Perhaps the reason for this finding has to do with contribution of various interactions between GQDs and H3O [30]. For example, as described in the higher activity structures of pN-H3O-GQD and prN-H3O-GQD, hydrogen atom is separated from the hydronium ion and bonds to a carbon atom, the electrostatic interaction between HOH donor and H acceptor forms a hydrogen bond, and a covalent bond is formed between hydrogen atom and carbon atom, which are Van der Waals interaction and chemical bonding, respectively. While for pN-OH-GQD and prN-OH-GQD, a strong interaction is formed between OH group and GQDs. Further, the hybrid orbitals of carbon atom change from the sp2 hybrid to sp3 hybrid after bonding with hydrogen atom. This finding demonstrates that strong interaction produced by functionalized groups in electrocatalysts can enhance their ORR catalytic activity. To explore the solvent effect, the ORR reaction path of GQDs in gas phase and toluene solvent conditions were further calculated through citing pN-OH-GQD, pN-H3O-GQD, prN-OH-GQD, and prN-H3O-GQD as examples. The Gibbs free energy changes of each elementary step for ORR on their surfaces in gas phase, toluene, and water conditions under Ueq = 1.23 V are listed in Table S2 and the corresponding free energy change diagram displayed in Fig. S9. As shown in Table S2, compared with the free energy change of each elementary step in water, the variations of free energy changes in gas phase and toluene are obvious, which indicates that the solvation effect has an important impact on ORR performances. It is probably worth noting that the overpotentials have larger values in gas phase and are reduced with the increase of solvent polarity (toluene < water). As can be seen in Fig. S9, the free energy change trends of most GQDs are generally similar in different solvent conditions, except for some steps of prN-OH-GQD in gas phase and pN-OH-GQD in water, and the RDS of prN-OH-GQD in gas phase changes to the second step of *O formation. Hence, it can be concluded that the ORR catalytic activity can be improved by tuning the solvent conditions based on solvent polarity. 3.5 Electron transfer analysis The formation of chemical bonds is always accompanied by electron recombination, especially for the covalent bond. The electron density difference (EDD) can reveal the electron transfer and bonding characteristics in chemical reactions. Hence, EDD was employed to explore the process of oxygen adsorption on GQDs. The electron density change Δρ of the oxygen adsorption process can be defined as: Δρ = ρ(O2/GQDs) – ρ(GQDs) – ρ(O2), where ρ(O2/GQDs), ρ(GQDs) and ρ(O2) are the electron density of entire GQDs adsorbed system, isolated GQDs and O2 molecule for the adsorbed system, respectively. The positive and negative value indicate the increase and decrease of electron density, respectively. The schematic diagram of EDD and the isosurfaces of EDD are displayed in Figs. 6 and S10. The yellow area represents the accumulating of electrons, and cyan area represents the loss of electrons. Some electrons assemble around the O2 molecule, implying that there is an apparent electron transfer from GQDs to O2 molecule. For pN-OH-GQD, pN-H3O-GQD, prN-OH-GQD and prN-H3O-GQD, the regions where electron-hole pairs appear are larger and more symmetrical than other structures. Oxygen adsorption energies Eads of pN-OH-GQD, pN-H3O-GQD and prN-H3O-GQD (Fig. 3) are close to 0. This indicates that GQDs with bonding H3O or OH groups can improve the electron transfer of reaction process efficiently than those GQDs with other structures, leading to a neither too strong nor too weak oxygen adsorption strength. Consequently, the subsequent reaction step can proceed favorably attributing to moderate adsorption strength of oxygen. Therefore, oxygen adsorption is a key step in ORR. The groups that effectively increase electron transfer can control oxygen adsorption strength within a reasonable range and further balance the adsorption strength of other intermediates. 3.6 Activity analysis The volcano plot has been widely considered as a valid tool to identify the activity of different catalysts and provides an effective guide for the selection and development of high efficiency electrocatalysts [63]. Generally, the catalyst at the top of the volcano plot has the minimum overpotential and high catalytic activity in thermodynamics. To reveal the ORR catalytic activity of overall N-doped GQDs (gN-GQDs, pN-GQDs and prN-GQDs), the activity volcano plots are established using the overpotential as a function of adsorption free energy ΔG*OH . The data of gN-GQDs were obtained through our previous study [34]. The adsorption free energies ΔG*OOH, ΔG*O and ΔG*OH of intermediates can be defined based on the free energy change of each elementary step [63–65]. For the adsorption free energies, a linear relationship was found between them and plotted in Figs. 7 (a) and S11, which are ΔG*OOH = 0.83ΔG*OH + 3.72 eV and ΔG*O = 0.92ΔG*OH + 1.19 eV, respectively. Substituting the linear relationships to the free energy change of each elementary step, it can be found that there is a specific corresponding relationship between ΔGi and ΔG*OH : (9) Δ G 1 = Δ G * OOH − 4.92 = 0.83 Δ G * OH − 1.20 eV (10) Δ G 2 = Δ G * O − Δ G * OOH = 0.09 Δ G * OH − 2.53 eV (11) Δ G 3 = Δ G * OH − Δ G * O = 0.08 Δ G * OH − 1.19 eV (12) Δ G 4 = − Δ G * OH So ΔGi can be expressed by only one variable ΔG*OH , and according to the Eq. (8), the ΔG*OH can be employed as the descriptor of overpotential. As depicted in Fig. 7(a), the slope and intercept of the linear relationship are close to previous studies [66,67]. The ideal values of ΔG*OH (1.23 eV) and ΔG*OOH (3.69 eV) are marked with a green star. For the volcano plots in Fig. 7(b), prN-GQD, prN-OH–-GQD and prN-H3O+-GQD lie on the left branch of volcano plots, which implies that adsorption strength of *OH is too strong, this may be the reason for relatively low catalytic activity of prN-GQDs. This phenomenon can also confirm that their RDS is the last step in the formation of the second water molecule after the formation of *OH intermediate. What's more, these prN-GQD with strong *OH adsorption strength usually have strong O2 adsorption strength, so the step of O2 adsorption would affect subsequent ORR steps. Instead, most of gN-GQDs and pN-GQDs lie on the middle and right branch, implying moderate and weak adsorption strength and their activity are generally higher than prN-GQDs. For the structures with the same adsorbate (i.e., pN-H3O-GQD, prN-H3O-GQD and gN-H3O-GQD), it can be concluded that the approximate order of three N-doped GQDs activity is gN-GQDs > pN-GQDs > prN-GQDs through the comparison of overpotentials. Moreover, there are four structures at the peak of volcano plots, which are gN-H3O-GQD, gN-OH-GQD, prN-OH-GQD and pN-H3O-GQD as the order of catalytic activity. Their ΔG*OH, ΔG*OOH and ΔG*O are close to the ideal value of 1.23 eV, 3.69 eV and 2.46 eV, respectively, represented by green stars in Figs. 7(a) and S9. Thus the presence of neutral species, such as H3O and OH groups, can enhance ORR activity among studied N-doped GQDs, especially pyrrolic-N doped GQDs. 4 Conclusion In this work, the ORR electrocatalytic properties of pN-GQDs and prN-GQDs were investigated, and the roles of four functionalized ions/groups were also discussed. The analysis of electrostatic potential and electronic structure imply that N doping can alter charge distributions and produce potential active sites, and the OH and H3O groups can further change overall electronic properties, increase active sites and improve ORR catalytic activity. The free energy change and overpotential show that pN-H3O-GQD and prN-OH-GQD are two functionalized structures with the highest activity, and the reason is that charge distributions of initial pN-GQD and prN-GQD structures are greatly changed due to the existence of H3O and OH. Electron density difference analysis also shows that transferred electron-hole pairs in these structures are significantly more than others in oxygen adsorption and related reactions, which can make intermediates with moderate binding strength. Although other intermediates in some GQD structures are more difficult to form than intermediate *OO, the step of oxygen adsorption is still the key factor to determine whether subsequent reactions and the whole ORR can be carried out easily, and oxygen adsorption energy requires a moderate value that is neither too high nor too low. In addition, solvent polarity affects the ORR catalytic activities of GQDs, thus the activity can be improved by tuning solvent conditions. It is anticipated that this study will contribute to fundamental insights into electrocatalytic mechanisms of hydronium and hydroxide ions/groups on GQDs and enhanced ORR activity of N-doped GQDs, and push forward their applications in fuel cells and metal-air batteries. coredata.dc:description: In this study, density functional theory was used to investigate the differences of oxygen reduction reaction catalytic activities between pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N doped graphene quantum dots (GQDs) and the influence of four ions/groups: OH–, H3O+, OH and H3O on their electronic properties. Free energy change calculations show that pyridinic-N doped GQDs (pN-GQDs) have better catalytic activities than pyrrolic-N doped GQDs (prN-GQDs). Moreover, the catalytic activity of both pN-GQDs and prN-GQDs can be enhanced via the functionalization of OH and H3O groups, which greatly alters electronic structures of the GQDs and thereby the adsorption strength of reactants can be effectively controlled. The findings can shed light on the effects of different N doping configurations and adsorbed species on electrocatalytic activities and provide theoretical guidelines for design and development of carbon-based oxygen reduction reaction electrocatalysts for fuel cells and metal-air batteries.
coredata.dc:title: Exploring the underlying oxygen reduction reaction electrocatalytic activities of pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N doped graphene quantum dots
